symptoms.name: Mother yaw (primary lesion)
symptoms.severity: Variable, can be painless or itchy
symptoms.pattern: Single papilloma (wart-like tumor) initially, may ulcerate; most often on limbs; incubation period 9-90 days

symptoms.name: Secondary yaws
symptoms.severity: Variable, can range from mild to severe
symptoms.pattern: Multiple raised yellow lesions, pain and swelling of long bones and fingers (dactylitis), weeks to months after primary infection

symptoms.name: Tertiary yaws
symptoms.severity: Severe, can lead to disfigurement and disability
symptoms.pattern: Skin and bone lesions, deformities of legs, nose, palate, and upper jaw; occurs in up to 20% of untreated cases, years after infection

symptoms.name: Fever
symptoms.pattern: Can be present, especially in secondary yaws

symptoms.name: Pallor
symptoms.pattern: Can be present, associated with anemia

lab_values.Treponema pallidum particle agglutinatio: Positive in treponemal infections (cannot distinguish yaws from syphilis)
lab_values.Rapid plasma reagin (RPR): Positive in treponemal infections (cannot distinguish yaws from syphilis)
lab_values.Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): Detects T. pallidum subspecies pertenue DNA in skin lesions; can monitor azithromycin resistance
lab_values.Hemoglobin: May be low (e.g., 3.9 mg/dL, indicative of anemia)

risk_factors: Living in poor communities in warm, humid, tropical areas
Contact with skin sores of infected individuals
Age under 15 years (most common in 6-10 year olds)

required: Clinical presentation consistent with yaws (papilloma, ulcer, etc.)
Positive serological test (TPPA, RPR, TPHA, VDRL)
supportive: Darkfield examination of skin lesion showing T. pallidum subspecies pertenue

differential_diagnoses: Other tropical diseases (e.g., mycobacterial disease, cutaneous leishmaniasis, fungal infections)
